item.title: Simulating Power
item.description: Experimental power When we conduct hypothesis tests there are two kinds of error: \(\alpha\) (which we set, typically at \(5\%\)) and \(\beta\). \(\alpha\) is the probability of making a Type I error: rejecting a null or primary hypothesis when it was correct. \(\beta\) is the probability of making a Type II error: failing to reject the null or primary hypothesis when the alternative is correct. \(\beta\) can be tricky since we donâ€™t set it directly.
